trustfund: TF035147-BRAZIL - AIDS AND STD CONTROL PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, borrower and World Bank
            performance were rated as satisfactory. Project objectives
            were largely met within the projected timetable. Most state
            and municipalities performed very well, and participation by
            nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) exceeded expectations.
            However two major problems not resolved during
            implementation were, first, evaluation was not satisfactory,
            making it impossible to quantify the impact of project
            interventions on high-risk behaviors and populations; and
            second, procurement activities subcontracted to third
            parties were inadequately supervised. Lessons learned
            included: The program's early efforts to build a
            constituency for the project among states, municipalities,
            and NGOs proved valuable in assuring a rapid project start
            up and timely project execution. NGO involvement was
            critical to reaching a number of high-risk populations. More
            attention is needed for evaluating staffing requirements and
            for effectively designing and implementing survey
            instruments. Greater attention to cost-effectiveness
            analysis of specific interventions would permit a better
            understanding of their relative priority in the overall AIDS
            and STD control program. Project management and the Bank
            need to more intensively supervise procurement activities
            contracted to third parties. Finally, the program could take
            better advantage of opportunities to integrate the various
            activities in prevention, surveillance, diagnosis,
            treatment, training, and evaluation.
